.factor-box:first-child {
  margin-top: 0;

.factor-box summary {
  padding: 20px 25px;
  cursor: pointer;
  list-style: none;
  font-weight: 600;
  color: #d97706;
  font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif;
  font-size: 1.3em;
  user-select: none;
  position: relative;
  transition: all 0.3s ease;
}

.factor-box summary::-webkit-details-marker {
  display: none;
}

.factor-box summary::before {
  content: '+';
  position: absolute;
  right: 25px;
  font-size: 1.5em;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: #d97706;
  transition: transform 0.3s ease;
}

.factor-box[open] summary::before {
  content: 'âˆ’';
  transform: rotate(0deg);
}

  background: rgba(217, 119, 6, 0.05);
}

.factor-box .factor-content {
  padding: 0 25px 20px 25px;
  color: #555;
  line-height: 1.8;
  font-size: 1.05em;
  animation: slideDown 0.3s ease;
}

@keyframes slideDown {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    transform: translateY(-10px);
  }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    transform: translateY(0);
  }
}

.factor-box:hover {

<div class="hero-section">
  <h1>Cognitive Decline & Alzheimer's Disease</h1>
</div>

<div class="content-section motivation-section">
  <h2>Motivation and Project Overview</h2>
  <p>As U.S. Alzheimer's disease (AD) cases are projected to reach <strong>7.2 million by 2025</strong>, identifying environmental and social risk factors such as age, sex and income, is urgent. We aim to inform prevention efforts by analyzing <strong>state-level variations</strong> in AD data. Our project investigates <strong>temporal</strong> and <strong>geographic</strong> trends in AD mortality and prevalence (2015-2016) to determine their association with education levels and air quality.</p>
</div>

<div class="content-section importance-section">
  <h2>Importance and Desire of Longevity</h2>
  <p>Over the years, people wonder about the maximum lifespan for human beings and how to achieve longevity with cognitive health. To that end, scientists have published numerous articles exploring perspectives such as genetics, diet, exercise, lifestyle habits, attitude, and stress management to prolong human life and maintain cognitive function. Although life expectancy has reached an 80-year high, limited resources and environmental challenges have made the goal of maximizing human cognitive health challenging. Understanding the factors that contribute to cognitive decline is crucial for developing effective prevention strategies.</p>
</div>

<div class="content-section factors-section">

  <h2>Associated Factors</h2>
  
```{=html}
<details class="factor-box">
  <summary>Cognitive Decline and Age</summary>
  <div class="factor-content">
    Age is the strongest known risk factor for cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease. The prevalence of cognitive problems increases significantly with age, particularly after 65 years. Understanding age-related patterns helps identify critical intervention points.
  </div>
</details>

<details class="factor-box">
  <summary>Cognitive Decline and Socioeconomic Status</summary>
  <div class="factor-content">
    Higher socioeconomic status, including education and income levels, is associated with lower rates of cognitive decline. Education may provide cognitive reserve, while income affects access to healthcare, healthy lifestyles, and living conditions that support brain health.
  </div>
</details>

<details class="factor-box">
  <summary>Cognitive Decline and Environmental Factors</summary>
  <div class="factor-content">
    Environmental exposures, particularly air pollution (PM2.5), have been linked to increased risk of cognitive decline and neurodegenerative diseases. Long-term exposure to poor air quality may accelerate cognitive aging and increase dementia risk.
  </div>
</details>
```

</div>

<div class="content-section">
  <h2>Key Findings</h2>
  
  <div class="stats-container">
<div class="stat-box">
  <div class="stat-number">32,616</div>
  <p>Total observations from CDC Healthy Aging Data across <strong>59 states and territories</strong></p>
</div>

<div class="stat-box">
  <div class="stat-number">47.9%</div>
  <p>Highest cognitive decline prevalence observed in <strong>Puerto Rico</strong> among adults 65+</p>
</div>

<div class="stat-box">
  <div class="stat-number">30.9% vs 26.8%</div>
  <p><strong>Women</strong> reported higher cognitive burden than <strong>men</strong> across all states</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="content-section">
  <h2>Research Questions</h2>
  <p>Our analysis addresses the following key questions:</p>
  
  <ol>
    <li><strong>Geographic Variation</strong>: How does the prevalence of self-reported cognitive decline vary across U.S. states and territories?</li>
    
    <li><strong>Demographic Patterns</strong>: Are there differences in cognitive burden by age group and sex?</li>
    
    <li><strong>Socioeconomic Factors</strong>: Is state-level median household income associated with cognitive decline prevalence?</li>
    
    <li><strong>Educational Attainment</strong>: Does the proportion of adults with higher education relate to cognitive outcomes?</li>
    
    <li><strong>Environmental Exposures</strong>: Is air pollution (PM2.5) associated with cognitive decline at the state level?</li>
  </ol>
</div>
